The Caring for Climate Series

The Caring for Climate Series is a collection of reports designed to foster business leadership in reducing the impacts and risks of climate change. They are produced either at the request of the UN Global Compact Office or as a contribution by leading business, academic and civil society entities in support of the Caring for Climate programme. The Series provides useful analysis and practical guidance to aid companies to develop effective climate strategies that will at the same time bring value to the company.

The Caring for Climate Series will be launched at the World Business Summit on Climate Change, on 24-26 May in Copenhagen, Denmark.

Carbon Markets – the Simple Facts

Lead author: Mission Climat of Caisse des Dép ôts.

This report provides down-to-earth guidance to the benefits, pitfalls and best practices in setting up carbon trading schemes that work for the environment, facilitate access to technology and foster economic development.

Caring for Climate – Best Practices and Policy Expectations

Lead author: GlobeScan.

Based on in-depth interviews and an extensive survey of Caring for Climate signatories, this report will highlight current best practices as well as expectations for public policies could facilitate and amplify such best practice.

Emerging Leadership: Climate Strategies and Practices in Developing Economies

Lead author: the Centre for Social Markets.

This study will look at leadership examples and practices from business in the largest, fastest developing economies. It will highlight trends, analyze challenges and opportunities, as well as investigate the influence of existing and expected public policies.

Energy Efficiency and Low Carbon Intensity: Are We Making Progress?

Lead author: Yale University, School of Forestry and Environment and Centre for Business and Environment.

This study will evaluate actual time series of energy efficiency and carbon emissions taken from public reports of Caring for Climate signatories in order to get a picture of progress and measuring methodologies used.

Making Energy Efficiency Investable

Lead author: HSBC.

Energy efficiency is the cheapest and fastest way of delivering carbon reductions. But it is hampered by institutional and financial bottlenecks, most recently highlighted by the World Bank's Financing Energy Efficiency report. This report defines the investment opportunity in energy efficiency and highlights the financial, business and policy innovations that are required to realize this potential.

Social Change, Policies and Competitive Advantage in a Lower Carbon Economy

Lead author: Goldman Sachs.

Increasing social awareness of climate change and policy responses have the potential to create new sources of competitive advantage in established industries and to drive growth in new technology areas and markets.  This study will assess the importance of climate change to financial investors, its impact on competitve advantage in established industries and the opportunities created as new industries develop. By assessing their performances on measures reflecting the range of challenges and opportunities climate change represents, it will compare companies' relative positions and the effectiveness of their responses in established industries.

UN Principles for Responsible - Investment in Action

Lead author: UN Principles for Responsible Investment.

Taking stock of investors’ practices on climate, this report will focus on the economic rationale for collective action by investors on carbon disclosure, investment choices, policy engagement. It will also map policy options that reduce investor’s risks.

Please note that there are still sponsorship opportunities available for several reports in this Series.
